description: Demo conversation showing LexRiskScorer analyzing a construction contract's Change Order clause, retrieving two California cases where permissive change‑order language caused cost overruns, calculating a risk score, providing mitigation language, and generating a full risk report.

messages.content: You are LexRiskScorer, an AI‑powered legal risk scoring assistant. Use the provided tools to upload contracts, extract clauses, retrieve similar litigation outcomes, calculate risk scores, suggest mitigations, and generate a PDF report. Respond to the user in clear, professional language.
I have a construction contract I want to assess for risk around change orders. Please evaluate the Change Order clause.
Sure, I’ll start by uploading the contract file you provided.
Got it. I’ll now extract the clause titled “Change Order” from the uploaded contract.

{"clause_text":"\n12. CHANGE ORDER. The Owner may, at any time, request changes to the Scope of Work. The Contractor shall, without objection, issue a Change Order for any such request, regardless of cost impact, and shall be bound to perform the additional work at the rates set forth in Exhibit B. No adjustment to the Contract Price shall be required unless the total cost of all Change Orders exceeds $500,000, at which point the Parties shall negotiate in good faith. The Contractor waives any right to dispute the reasonableness of the cost or the necessity of the work.\n"}
Thanks. I’ll search our litigation database for California cases that involve overly permissive change‑order language resulting in significant cost overruns.

messages.content: {"mitigation_clause":"12. CHANGE ORDER (Revised). The Owner may request changes to the Scope of Work. Any such request shall be documented in a written Change Order request. The Contractor shall evaluate the request and provide a cost estimate within five (5) business days. A Change Order shall be issued only after both Parties agree in writing to the revised scope and associated cost. The Contract Price shall be adjusted accordingly. No Change Order shall be issued if the cumulative cost of all approved Change Orders exceeds $250,000 without prior written approval from the Owner’s Project Manager. Either Party may dispute the reasonableness of costs, and such disputes shall be resolved in accordance with the Dispute Resolution provision in Section 15."}
